entry.title: Reminders
entry.content:
A few things:

  • The second exam is on Tuesday, 11/19. The exam will have the same structure as the first exam. I will announce four essay questions, from which I will choose one, on Thursday.
  • If you have not done so, I recommend you re-read Lewis’ ‘Mad Pain and Martian Pain’.
  • For Thursday, please read Block’s ‘Troubles with Functionalism’ (Chalmers).

entry.title: Update on readings for Thursday
entry.content: For Thursday, you should feel free to read either one of the two Lewis readings on the schedule. The Kim reading is optional.

entry.title: New online Quiz
entry.content:
There’s a new quiz for you to take on the Moodle site. Make sure you re-read Dretske’s paper before taking it. You will have 20 minutes to complete the quiz. You have until Friday at 5pm to complete it.

Also, on Thursday we will finish up our discussion of Dretske before moving on to discuss the assigned reading for that day.

entry.title: Updates
entry.content:
There’s been a minor update to the reading schedule, as announced in class last Thursday.

Also, there’s an extra credit assignment on the Moodle website. You have until Monday at 5pm to complete it. Once you start the quiz, you will have ten minutes to complete it.

Let me know if you have any questions.

entry.title: Turing Machine simulator
entry.content: The Turing Machine simulator we use in class last week is available here. Check it out!

entry.title: A few updates
entry.content:
First, the reading schedule has been updated. Let me know if you have any questions about that.

Second, the second exam will take place on Tuesday 11/19 (and not on Thursday 11/14, as originally planned). I will update the course calendar accordingly.

Third, I am going to try an experiment. For the next few meetings, I will put up the slides for each class on the Moodle website. This will allow you to review them after class in case you need to. The slides from today’s class are available here.

entry.title: This week
entry.content:
A few things:

  • There will be no class on Thursday, 10/24.
  • For similar reasons, I will not be holding office hours on Thursday, 10/24.
  • However, I will be holding office hours tomorrow from 10.45 until 12, in the usual place.
  • Finally, if it is not too inconvenient, please bring your laptop with you to class tomorrow.

entry.title: Reminder
entry.content: As I mentioned in class on Tuesday, there are no additional readings for Thursday. But please make sure to go over the Kripke reading once again.

entry.title: Two things
entry.content:
First: following up on our discussion last Thursday, here is Chomsky’s review of B. F. Skinner’s Verbal Behavior.

Second: there was a typo on the readings for next week. It’s been fixed now. If you tried to look for a section titled ‘What Does ’‘Identity’‘ Mean?’ in chapter 3 of Kim’s book, you probably realized that there was a typo. But for the record: all readings from Kim’s book for next week are from chapter 4.

entry.title: Adjustments
entry.content:
We are a little behind relative to the original reading schedule. So, for this coming Thursday, you should just reread the material assigned for today. In other words, here are the readings for Thursday:

  • Descartes, excerpts from The Passions of the Soul. (Chalmers).
  • Smullyan, ‘An Unfortunate Dualist’. (Chalmers)
  • Kim, chapter 2, read until the end of the section titled ‘Princess Elisabeth against Descartes’.

I will update the reading schedule shortly.

entry.title: Readings for Thursday
entry.content: The readings for Thursday’s class are now available in electronic form on the readings page. Starting next week, I will assume you each have access to the required books for this class.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.content:
This is the website for PHIL 355 at UMass Amherst. Announcements, readings, and other relevant information will be posted here. If you are enrolled in this class, you should be checking this website regularly, as well as the course calendar.

For your convenience, I have set up a mailing list for this course. I encourage you to subscribe in order to be notified of announcements on this site. Note, however, that you will only be notified of updates to the site once a day. (If there are no new updates on a given day, you will receive no emails.)

I have also set up a Moodle page for this website. However, we will only use that page for two purposes: you will submit your assignments there, and you will be able to review your grades for the course. If I ever need you to check the Moodle page I will make sure to make an announcement on this page.

If you are enrolled in this class, or are thinking about enrolling, you may want to take a look at the course syllabus. (N.B.: I will not distribute paper copies on the first day of class.)
